required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Coronary Artery Disease Management Using Multislice Computed Tomography and Magnetic Resonance Imaging
clinical_study.official_title: Coronary Artery Disease Management Using Multislice Computed Tomography and Magnetic Resonance Imaging

collaborator.agency: Medizinische Hochschule Hannover, Eva Schönenberger, MD

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of this study is to analyze the clinical value of a therapeutic management strategy based on the results of coronary CT angiography and functional MRI. The clinical value of CT and MRI will be analyzed in patients with suspected coronary artery disease.

primary_outcome.time_frame: during or up to 2 days after procedures
primary_outcome.description: Death, stroke, and myocardial infarction and moderate to severe groin hematoma, groin pain, infections, allergies, thromboses, and arteriovenous fistula or other complications (if prolonging the in-hospital stay significantly by at least 24 hours).

secondary_outcome.description: Composite endpoint: The most important secondary outcome will be hard cardiovascular events at final follow-up (3 years). These hard events include: cardiac and noncardiac death (death from any cause), stroke, and myocardial infarction. These hard events are considered as major adverse cardiovascular events.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Follow-up 1 (6-12 Months), Follow-up 2 (12-24 Months), Follow-up 3 (36-60 Months)
secondary_outcome.description: To compare contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) defined as increase in creatinine by 25% or 0.5 mg/dl from baseline at the measurements obtained 18 to 24 and/or 46 to 50 hours after the initial procedures as part of standard safety parameters performed at our institution. In addition, CIN will also be assessed during the follow-ups.

secondary_outcome.measure: Comparison of Comparison of Soft Cardiovascular Events
secondary_outcome.description: To compare soft cardiovascular events (unstable angina pectoris, re-revascularization, and first revascularization at least 2 months after randomization, according to the results of Ladenheim et al. J Am Coll Cardiol 1986, at final follow-up.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 24 hours after the end of the in-hospital stay.
secondary_outcome.description: to compare the in-hospital stay time and overall length of stay.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Follow-up 1 (6-12 Months), Follow-up 2 (12-24 Months), Follow-up 3 (36-60 Months)
secondary_outcome.description: To analyze the change in quality of life (QALY) in both groups (prior to the tests and at follow-up) using the SF-12 and the EuroQuol as general measurement tools and the MacNew questionnaire as disease-specific questionnaire.

secondary_outcome.measure: Confounding Effects of Nutrition, Physical Activity, and Depression
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Follow-up 1 (6-12 Months), Follow-up 2 (12-24 Months), Follow-up 3 (36-60 Months)
secondary_outcome.description: To analyze the effect and potentially confounding effect of nutrition, physical activity (using the Freiburg questionnaire), and depression (assessed with the HADS questionnaire) in the two groups.
To compare cost-effectiveness in both groups using the primary and secondary efficacy data, the QALY data, and cost data derived from the trial.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: 24 hours after last procedure related to computed tomography or conventional coronary angiography
secondary_outcome.description: To analyze patient preference and satisfaction with the therapeutic management strategies with a focus on the comfort during the imaging tests.

secondary_outcome.measure: Comparison of the Amount of Contrast Agent
secondary_outcome.description: Comparison of the amount of contrast agent

secondary_outcome.measure: Comparison of the Amount of Radiation Exposure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Comparison of the amount of radiation exposure
secondary_outcome.description: 10 minutes after computed tomography or conventional coronary angiography

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 24 hours after the end of computed tomography
secondary_outcome.description: To analyze which image quality in multislice computed coronary angiography would be required to directly reliably triage patients to coronary artery bypass grafting.

secondary_outcome.measure: Analysis of Correlation and Agreement About the Stenosis Diameter Between Multislice Computed Coronary Angiography and Conventional Coronary Angiography
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to 24 hours after the end of computed tomography
secondary_outcome.description: To analyze the correlation and agreement between multislice computed coronary angiography and conventional coronary angiography (using quantitative analysis) for estimation of the percent diameter stenosis in patients who underwent both tests.

secondary_outcome.measure: Comparison of Biological Effects of Radiation Exposure
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Z1) before exam, (Z2) 60 min after end of exam, (Z3) 18-24h after exam
secondary_outcome.description: To compare the biological effects of radiation exposure of ionizing radiation, measured by DNA double-strand breaks in lymphocytes, of CT and conventional coronary angiography themselves and in the two randomization groups (approval by ethics board for this substudy with start of first patient analyzed on September, 15, 2009). Blood samples are taken for double-strand break analysis.

intervention.description: Standard clinical management directed by conventional coronary angiography

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Suspected coronary artery disease and planned conventional coronary angiography based on atypical angina pectoris
Exclusion Criteria:
- Known coronary artery disease
- ST elevation
- Age below 30 years
- Women of child-bearing potential without a negative pregnancy test
- Inclusion in another study
- Heart rate above 70 beats per min and contraindications to beta blockers
- Atrial fibrillation or uncontrolled tachyarrhythmia, or advanced atrioventricular block
- Inability to hold the breath for 10 s

Evaluation of computed tomography in patients with atypical angina or chest pain clinically referred for invasive coronary angiography: randomised controlled trial.
